💭 Update 2023-12-07

2023.12.07

100 Days to Offload

I'm definitely behind a bit. Time off for Thanksgiving is a large part of the reason. I didn't get any posts written that week I believe, and only one last week. Actually, I think I was a week or so ahead, and 2 a week would be more than 100 posts, so maybe I'm just back on track as opposed to ahead. I don't feel like mathing out where I should be. I'm just going to try to get more posts done so I don't actually fall behind or fall behind further.

Mastodon

I've just not been feeling Mastodon lately. I think I may just take some time off from it. I don't think I'll even post this there. It just often feels like it doesn't provide a ton given the time I put in to reading every post in my feed. I much prefer emails. Feel free to send me one if you'd like! 0xdstn@protonmail.com

Advent of Code

Still going on this! I skipped day 5 part 2, because it was incredibly difficult and I don't care enough to put more time into that. I did however finish 6, so all I have left that is available at the time of writing this is today's, day 7. I hear it's difficult, so we'll see if I get it done. I may be getting close to my limit for this year, but I'll stick it out as long as it stays fun.

Toki Pona

I've decided to start attempting to learn toki pona again. I am trying out Anki this time. It seems to be going well actually, I think I've learned a couple new words and gotten more confident on the ones that were less automatic for me. I already know most toki pona words, but I have some that are really difficult to get to stick for some reason. Hoping this will result in me knowing all of them. I then will work on reading things such as lipu tenpo. I'd also like to write more in toki pona, either in my journal or on here. I did write a haiku the other day:

telo sewi o
telo mute lon ale
kasi li pona

This roughly translates to:

rain!
a lot of water is on everything
the plant is happy

💭 Toki Pona Section

2023.12.08

Since I am trying to take my learning toki pona seriously, I've created a new section on my site for it!

I will only be writing in toki pona on the pages of that section. I am also using the linja pona font to display toki pona in sitelen pona. This would probably look weird in a RSS feed because sometimes you use hyphens and brackets and things to display compound glyphs, so I've excluded it from my RSS feed. At some point I may create a separate toki pona feed that cleans it up a bit, for those that want to follow it. I also didn't want to bog down my RSS feed with a language people may not know.

I have only added one page so far, which is where I will keep my toki pona haiku: sitelen musi lili.

I am still learning toki pona, so if anyone reading this has some suggestions on my writing, please reach out and let me know so I can learn from it.

item.title: Update 2023-12-12
item.dc:creator: ~dustin
item.description:
💭 Update 2023-12-12

2023.12.12

SQL Murder Mystery

I was linked to this SQL Murder Mystery challenge and it was really fun! It was a good combination of not too challenging, but also not boring. It didn't take me longer than half an hour (probably not even that) to solve it. You don't have to know a ton of SQL to solve it, just the basics will do, so if you're into that kind of thing you should try it out!

Secret Satan + Work

As I mentioned before, I'm listening to The Christmas Stories Podcast, which is currently running a season called Secret Satan. It's a workplace murder mystery, and I've found it really entertaining!

It all hits close to home because they work in a large company, characters that are backend developers, frontend developers, designers, etc. It often dives into how soul crushing and terrible working in a large corporation can be. In today's episode it went on a little rant about how due to capitalism, we work because we have to, not because we want to, and how we work with all these people that we probably wouldn't choose to know outside the corporate setting. It made me think of my previous post on work focus where I talked about not feeling motivated at work and wanting to be doing other things, like making art.

Even if you do a job that is something you enjoy (such as writing code), the corporate setting where you're building someone else's dream is the problem. We rarely care about the actual product we're building in the sense that we wouldn't be building it if someone else wasn't paying us to. Even if you like to code, it's what you're coding that defines if it's enjoyable or not.

I really enjoy making little apps for myself, and I tolerate making apps for a company.

I don't mean to imply that I'm not happy at my job. I am. I am grateful that I have it. It's very flexible, fairly low stress, and pays well. I wouldn't want to be somewhere else, but I can also acknowledge the feelings that capitalism is terrible and we are all just putting so much energy into something that we don't truly want to be doing.

Advent of code

Guess I'm done with this, as I just kind of quit trying. I made it through day 6, minus part 2 of day 5. Maybe I'll get farther next year lol It's fun while it lasts though, and that's always my goal with it. I only want to do it as long as it's fun, and stop when I no longer care to do it without feeling bad for quitting.

item.title: 2024 Plans
item.dc:creator: ~dustin
item.description:
💭 2024 Plans

2023.12.18

I want to have some major personal growth next year. I have a few ideas about how I want to do this, but here are some ideas:

Quarterly focus

I'm considering setting a focus for each quarter around something I'd like to learn more about. Here is a rough plan:

  • Q1 (JAN-MAR): Witchcraft
  • Q2 (APR-JUN): Buddhism
  • Q3 (JUL-SEP): Bug Bounty
  • Q4 (OCT-DEC): Writing

I'm not going to hold myself to these in the sense that I won't learn about anything else during those months, but I'd like to have a more focused plan for learning about specific topics.

I will also adjust them if I don't feel like doing one in a particular quarter. It'll be a work in progress as I go.

I will also continue learning about other topics throughout these, such as art, nature, etc.

As I learn about these things, I will be taking notes in Obsidian and sometimes transcribe the notes to this site or my physical notebooks (Bullet Journal and/or Book of Shadows).

Reading

As I mentioned in my previous post about reading goals, I decided this year to switch to my own book tracking system and not set a goal for myself.

With this shift, I ended up not reading very many. If I don't finish anything else in the next two weeks, I will have read 16 books, which is the lowest amount I've ever read since before 2019.

I like the fact that I'm managing my books with my own system, so I will keep that up, however I don't like how I did not prioritize reading. While reading goals can cause me to read a bunch of small things to hit the goal, at least I was reading. I just simply have not read as much as I'd like this year.

I have decided that in 2024 I will set a goal again. I am going to set it to 30, which I know I can hit, and may even exceed.

I am hoping that this will motivate me to read more again, as I'm pretty disappointed with the amount of books I've read this year. This will also hopefully help me abandon books I'm not really into, which has been a challenge for me in the past. If I am not reading something, maybe I'm not actually interested in it and I should switch to something more interesting.

I'm looking forward to 2024 being another reading year, as the last few years have been prior to 2023.

Art

I tend to get in my own way with art, expecting myself to sit down and do something detailed and focused every time. I would like to switch to doing this sometimes, but mostly just drawing quick things every day. I've tried this before, but I'm going to give it a go again, with a healthier mindset. I will not expect myself to draw every single day, but I will still challenge myself to do it as many days as I can, and get close to every day. I will do a small drawing with a fountain pen of something in my life. It doesn't have to be detailed or painted or written about or laid out in a fancy way. I just want to draw little glimpses of my days.

A huge inspiration for this is the Instagram account carnetsbruns. They post weekly collections of small and messy ink drawings from life. I'd like to do the same. I will plan to post them in groups (probably not exactly every week though) in my art section.

Health

I really need to get my health under control, so I will work on making small changes (Kaizen style). I want to get in a habit of doing low impact physical activity daily and making more mindful choices about what I eat and how much I eat. I may try intermittent fasting and cutting down sugar again. Both of those have helped me with weight management in the past, as well as making me feel better in general.

I am hoping to make 2024 a great year!

item.title: Technology Usage
item.dc:creator: ~dustin
item.description:
💭 Technology Usage

I have long struggled with balancing privacy and convenience. In an ideal world, I would only use software that is open source and does not track me or have ads. In practice, this is not an easy feat by any means. I have gone through times of attempting to switch everything I use to more privacy conscious and/or FOSS alternatives. Some open source software is great, but some things require so many hoops and a certain level of lost productivity in order to use it over an alternative owned by a company such as Google.

I don't want to make privacy my identity, but I would like to specifically choose better options if they work well for me. If they don't, I will use what does, even if it's a system owned by a large corporation.

For instance, I am once again using Google Keep for notes on my phone. I have notes saved elsewhere, digitally and physically, but for easy notes without the risk of losing them if my phone dies, I will use Keep.

Another thing I've previously tried to abandon, but it's not worth the struggle, is Dropbox and Enpass. I use Dropbox to manage my Enpass vault, and it all just works. I don't want to struggle with nextcloud and keepass or something similar for very little privacy gain. I will use what works.

Because of Dropbox, I've also tended to stay away from Obsidian, but I've decided I would like to use that again for research and getting things down to be filtered into other places (this site, physical bullet journal, physical book of shadows, etc). I think it will work really well for me, and that's what I need, not extra stress of using something subpar or trying to build and manage my own.

I know this may not be a popular opinion amongst the people who read my site, but it is what works for me and I value my time more than my ideals when it comes to what technology I use. That doesn't mean that I will just mindlessly accept whatever is available though. I will always carefully pick what technologies I use. Sometimes I will build my own, sometimes I'll select something FOSS, sometimes I'll go with an application owned by a corporation because it works for me and saves me a lot of time and stress.

item.title: Update 2023-12-18
item.dc:creator: ~dustin
item.description:
💭 Update 2023-12-18

2023.12.18

Toki pona

I have switched my toki pona section to no longer use the sitelen pona font. I decided that others may not have decided to learn sitelen pona, so I would prefer it's more accessible to all toki pona speakers.

I also added a RSS feed for the toki pona section, so people who are interested in toki pona can follow that specifically.

I've been doing anki cards daily for a few weeks now, and it's going great! I've learned a few new words that I struggled to learn before. I have also had an interesting shift happen where I have a kind of recognition for words as opposed to translating them in my mind. So for instance I see "soweli" and don't think "An animal/mammal" I just know what it means. I feel like this is the next step of fluency, which is exciting!

Knowledge Management

I've tried many different knowledge management systems / note taking systems and I always end up not sticking with things for one reason or another. A lot of times I try to use something like Obsidian, and go into a mode where I try to cut out everything that isn't open source and just use my own note taking systems, etc. I also have this site, but I want something more personal. This is my plan:

I will start using Obsidian to take notes on various topics (such as my quarterly focus topics). I will probably also transcribe some of my notes either to this site, or to my physical books (Bullet Journal and/or Book of Shadows). I am also going to try to take daily notes so that I can have a history of the things I've read and looked into.

I am hoping this will be a good way to help gain value from my focus for each quarter.

Winter break

I have winter break coming up in a few days, and I will be completely offline during that time. It will be from December 21, 2023 to January 2, 2024. I am going to write a few posts this week (or more likely just today), that way I am caught up with 100DaysToOffload and can go into the new year ready to continue on that without being behind.

I hope you all have a wonderful holiday season and I'll see you all in the new year!

💭 Moon Planning

2024.01.02

I last wrote in my 2024 plans post that I was thinking of focusing on something each quarter (buddhism, witchcraft, etc). I've thought about it since and I have a new plan - set a focus for each moon cycle. This will allow me to switch it up more often (there are 12 full cycles this year). The new moon is a time for planning, and you can harness the moon's energy by setting intentions during a new moon.

This also opens it up so I have check in points (first quarter, full, and last quarter), where I can assess how I'm doing and make sure I'm staying on track.

When each new moon comes around I will reflect on the previous cycle, and determine the focus for the next cycle.

The first full moon is on January 11th, so I am going to spend this time planning exactly how these rituals will look, and determine what I want my first cycle's focus to be.

In addition to setting a focus and checking in on my progress of it on each moon phase, I am going to try out doing a personal reflection with every phase, to give myself a scheduled time to reflect on how things are going in general and make changes.

These are the new moons this year:

01/11, 02/09, 03/10, 04/08, 05/07, 06/06, 07/05, 08/04, 09/02, 10/02, 11/01, 11/30, 12/30

item.title: Without
item.dc:creator: ~dustin
item.description:
📝 Without

2024.01.03

I saw a post by Kev Quirk about "living without" and it ended up being a chain of posts based on other posts, so I read them all, including all the recap posts for the various experiments. These are the posts (in order of publish, oldest to newest, recaps are linked within the respective posts):

  • A Year of Living Without by zen habits
  • My year of living without by Manu
  • Yet another year of living without by Manu
  • One Month Without by Kev Quirk

There is a lot of interesting information throughout these posts. It got me thinking of some things I'd like to try out. I don't know that I want to go the Manu route and give up a couple things for a whole year. I also don't know that I want to do the giving up something every month thing, but I do want to work on cutting some things out and changing how I consume other things.

Coffee

This is a difficult one for me. I hated coffee for years, and in my early 20s, started taking a liking to it. I've since moved into loving coffee, owning multiple manual brewers, and drinking at least a cup a day, but sometimes more. I love coffee, and I do not want to remove it from my life.

That being said, I do want to change my relationship with coffee. As of writing this, I am addicted to coffee. Not only that, but I'm specifically addicted to black coffee. Drinking an espresso drink and/or tea does not work for me. Even if I have other drinks, containing the same amount of caffeine, I get a headache and/or don't feel good. Yes that sounds ridiculous, because it is.

I do not want to give up coffee entirely, but I would like to give up my addiction to it, and also make it something that I enjoy in the moment, not just something I consume every day.

Previously I exclusively drank tea before starting on coffee. I still love tea. Tea never gave me side effects when I didn't have any, and I feel better in general after drinking tea vs coffee. I would like to drink a tea each morning, and have coffee occasionally as a treat, not as a daily habit.

My plan is to slowly wean myself off of coffee so I no longer feel like I need it every day. I'll do this by lowering the amount I drink each day, and when I'm comfortable moving on to skipping days, until I've gotten through the withdrawal. At the same time I will start making a tea every morning, which should help some as I will still get caffeine.

Some benefits once I've succeeded in this will be:

  • Making tea is much easier for me than making coffee, as there is a lot of setup and cleanup with my coffee making ritual, so I will be able to have a tea even if I'm pressed for time.
  • I miss drinking tea and I think it will be a calming, enjoyable activity, even if I'm doing it every day. I'll do my best to make a moment of it instead of just taking it on the go. I view this as more of a ritual vs a habit.
  • I will be able to have coffee sometimes as a nice drink, and thus enjoy it more when I do have it.
  • I won't drink coffee I don't like when I'm in a rush, just for the sake of having coffee.
  • I will likely drink more water. When I go to pick up a drink, I'll have water available instead of coffee.

Sugar

A year or so ago my wife and I decided to go no sugar. I avoided foods with added sugars, tried to eat foods with less natural sugar when possible, and ate no sweets at all. This was great for both of us. I felt much better, lost a few pounds, no longer craved sweets, and could even notice the sugar content in foods like fruit, so things tasted better.

I will be doing something similar, but not as intense. I will actively work on selecting foods with a low or no sugar content, avoid foods with added sugar, and only have sweets as a small treat. This means not having a giant slice of cake, or multiple cookies, but truly enjoying a piece of dark chocolate. I want my sweet consumption to be small treats that I'm fully present in enjoying, as opposed to just flying through large desserts, making myself sick and not truly enjoying it.

Misc changes

Those are the main two things I will be doing, but I have some other things I am starting up as well:

  • Fasting: This has helped me in the past by preventing me from eating late at night, eating too much, and making unhealthy choices because I don't have time in the morning. I will make a good effort to fast at least 16 hours each day, but I will also allow myself to break it if it makes life much more difficult (like if my family is going out to breakfast or something).
  • Meat and dairy: Red meat and specifically dairy don't usually sit well with my stomach. I know that being vegan or vegetarian will not be possible with my current life, and I'm okay with that. I will, however, actively choose to limit these things in my diet. I will serve myself less meat and more vegetables when putting food on plates for dinner. I will choose to eat vegetarian when eating on my own, which is usually the case for breakfast and lunch. If I can opt to not have something or substitute something, without making my own food entirely while others have something else, I'll do that.
  • Sitting: I know sitting is bad for me and I do a lot of it. I already decided that every day I am in the office (weather and other things permitting) I will take a lunch walk. I will also start switching my desk to standing mode at work more often, and work at the counter more when at home.

Recap

I know this sounds like a lot, but really the coffee is the difficult/new thing here. I will easily be able to jump in to limiting sugar/meat/dairy in my diet, fasting again, and sitting less. These are just going to be things I have decided so I will do every day, while going easy on myself when I'm not doing perfectly. As long as I continue and do my best, that will be enough and they will turn into habits I don't even need to try to achieve.

So these are the things I will be doing:

  • Breaking my coffee habit/starting a tea ritual
  • Limit sugar in my diet
  • Limit meat and dairy in my diet
  • Go on lunch walks
  • Work standing when possible

item.title: Just Being
item.dc:creator: ~dustin
item.description:
💭 Just Being

2024.01.04

I am working on being more mindful and not constantly trying to distract myself from reality. I don't let myself just be, and I'm trying to do that more.

A couple times in the last few days I muted the radio in the car and just listened to the rain fall outside. Just driving and listening and being. It was nice, and I want to keep doing things like that. I've also managed to sit and enjoy tea or sit with one of my kids without allowing myself to pull out my phone. I always feel like I need to be doing something, but I simply don't.

There is just so much information and entertainment out there, and we can never consume it all. I don't want to be on social networks scrolling through things that I don't commit to my memory or provide me anything. I don't want to be constantly listening to podcasts, never being able to catch up on the 1000+ episodes I have across all the podcasts I want to listen to, which just keeps growing.

On the idea of podcast, I'm considering not subscribing to podcasts that post weekly or daily. I notoriously can't keep up with these and then feel I have to when I have a silent moment. I think I will unsubscribe from these:

  • Deep Questions with Cal Newport
  • The Way Out Is In

They are great podcasts, but I'm always behind, the episodes are so long, and I just never take the time to sit down to listen to them.

These I may not give up, but I am considering it. I'm not sure yet:

  • The SneakyArt podcast
  • BirdNote Daily

Bidnote is just a few minutes a day, so I think that may be fine, but I often end up not listening for many days and have a ton to get through.

The SneakyArt podcast is inspiring for making art, so that's a benefit enough to maybe keep it, but I'm choosing to listen to the backlog of episodes, so new ones are always popping up and it will take me a long time to catch up.

Podcasts aside, I just want to take more moments to just be and enjoy existing.

item.title: Sharing vs Meaning
item.dc:creator: ~dustin
item.description:
💭 Sharing vs Meaning

2024.01.04

I was reading through Wayfinding from Life Noticed, which really resonated with me. I was particularly drawn to this quote:

Culturally, I feel weve become so fixated on the sharing portion of our creative pursuits that we have stripped away the meaning behind what we make, granting everything and everyone but ourselves control over what we do and how often its due.

This is very true for me, and I'm sure many others. I get so caught up in sharing and set up self imposed deadlines, which really takes away from the experience of creating. Even writing here, I decided to do #100DaysToOffload, and before I took some time off for the holidays, I was constantly checking if I was on track with my post count, and sometimes I feel I wrote things just to get another post done. I don't want to do that. From now on I will write as often as I feel motivated to, and if I meet my goal, great, if not, oh well. If I don't do 100 posts in a year, I still wrote way more than I ever would have without deciding to join this challenge. I just want to make things because I enjoy it, and then I will share things not because I need to build a following, but because it's something I did so I'll just put it out there.

This also goes for art. I've struggled with that a lot, and wrote about it a lot. I get caught up in building an Instagram for it, or how I will make money off it, or try to force myself to draw every single day (which I always fail at within no more than a few days). I don't want to have this relationship with art. I want to create art for the sake of making art, while enjoying the process itself. I want to let go of my vision of the final product, or even my opinion of the final product, and soak in the process itself. I've read countless articles and books that tell you to stop caring about the outcome and enjoy the process, and I want to finally do that. I want to make art, any kind of art I feel inspired to make, regardless of what I feel I "should" make or what I think the outcome should be. Not only will this make it so I enjoy making art more, it will likely lead to art I like more. Here are some quotes I've written down from some of my favorite artists regarding this:

You get to the good stuff only if you are willing to go through the bad - Nashant Jain, The Sneaky Artist
You just have to try things and you have to be prepared that they won't all work. - Ali Foxon
It's more important to develop as an artist than grow your following - Mike Lowrey

item.title: Moon planning shift
item.dc:creator: ~dustin
item.description:
💭 Moon planning shift

2024.01.10

As mentioned in my Moon Planning post that I am going to work on planning and reflecting with the cycles of the moon. I have been thinking about it a lot, and I was going to set two focuses each cycle: A learning focus and a personal focus. I have since decided that I don't think that is what I want to do.

I am currently reading Moonology by Yasmin Boland. It is all about planning and making changes in your life with the moon cycles. I'm not too far into it, but it got me thinking about how the best use of my time during these cycles would be to make personal changes. Work on myself to become the best version of me I can be. I will be doing that, and since it's very personal I will not be sharing what my focuses are for each cycle.

I have decided not to add the learning focus to this. My plan was to focus on learning about the moon for this first cycle (starting tomorrow, January 11th), and I feel that limiting myself to a topic for about a month will likely cause me to lose interest in the topic or find it hard to seek new information about it before the cycle is over. I want to focus on learning whatever feels right at the moment, and not limit myself in this way. I have a lot of interests and I tend to bounce between them in rapid succession, and I don't feel like boxing myself in will promote more learning. I think it will just hinder it.

item.title: Priorities
item.dc:creator: ~dustin
item.description:
💭 Priorities

2024.01.17

This probably won't make much sense to others, but I have decided for personal reasons to stop writing on this site and to end my #100DaysToOffload challenge. I am finding that sharing here is causing a severe lack in sharing elsewhere in my life, and it is problematic for my relationships.

I'm grateful for everyone that has read what I've posted and encouraged me along the way.

I will leave the posts in the writing, thoughts, and changelog sections in place so they don't become dead links, but I will be hiding those sections from my navigation. I will still be adding posts to projects, art, recipes, and toki pona.

I have also decided to remove the wiki section from the nav as well, and no longer add anything there. I am currently duplicating information between that section, Obsidian, and my physical bullet journal and it's all just too much.

Again, I know this may not make sense to everyone, but I know that this is best for myself.

See you space cowboy...
